s.text: The "MMF Hall of Humiliation" Web site traces the "Make Money Fast" chains to their origins and lists addresses and phones of the alleged originators, requesting that you spam them.
The "Jessica Mydek" e-mail succeeds because it promises the replicator instant karma.
The "Jessica Mydek" e-mail succeeds because it promises the replicator instant karma.
Never mind, of course, that public broadcasting isn't under attack, that NPR receives little of its support directly from Congress, and that NPR spokespeople say the letter is useless.
The ubiquitous "Make Money Fast" e-mail recasts the classic pyramid scheme as e-scam: Send $5 to the names on the list, add your own name to the bottom, and reap your windfall later.
The ubiquitous "Make Money Fast" e-mail recasts the classic pyramid scheme as e-scam: Send $5 to the names on the list, add your own name to the bottom, and reap your windfall later.
The ubiquitous "Make Money Fast" e-mail recasts the classic pyramid scheme as e-scam: Send $5 to the names on the list, add your own name to the bottom, and reap your windfall later.
But let's not forget the upside to the chains.
But let's not forget the upside to the chains.
But let's not forget the upside to the chains.
A well-known postal chain, the St. Jude letter, claims a 1903 inception date.
Netizens translated it into other languages and it appeared around the world.
